name: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II
description: With a focus on fast-action RTS gameplay, Dawn of War II brings to life the science fiction universe of Warhammer 40,000 like never before. Experience the intimate brutality of battle as you play through your chosen race’s epic campaign.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP2 or Windows Vista SP1                     Processor: P4 3.2 GHz (single core) or any Dual Core processor                     Memory: 1 GB RAM (XP), 1.5 GB RAM (Vista)                     Graphics: A 128MB Video Card (Shader Model 3) - Nvidia GeForce 6600 GT / ATI X1600, or equivalent                     Hard Drive: 6.5 GB of uncompressed Hard Drive space                     REQUIRED FOR MULTIPLAYER:      INTERNET: Cable modem, DSL modem, or 56.6kbps modem for online multiplayer play: Network: TCP/IP compliant network
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP2 or Windows Vista SP1                     Processor: AMD Athlon 64x2 4400+ or any Intel Core 2 Duo                     Memory: 2 GB RAM (XP and Vista)                     Graphics: A 256MB Video Card (Shader Model 3) - Nvidia GeForce 7800 GT / ATI X1900, or equivalent                     Hard Drive: 6.5 GB of uncompressed Hard Drive space

reviews.review_text: 3 Awesome and largley different game modes  Campaign > control 4 squads, level up, find better Loot. You arent stuck with the same 4 squads either as they can be swapped for others ( dont like Scout marines, no problem, Dreadnaught?), some interesting boss battles aswell.   Last Stand > 3 player controlled heros must survive against hordes of enemies, 20 waves with special boss waves, fight the Eldar , Space Marines, Imperials, Tyranids , Orks and Chaos. Level each Hero to 20, unlocking more gear as you level, Play as An ork Mek Boy, Space Marine, or Eldar Farseer.   Multiplayer PVP or Ai > Small scale warfare heavily focused on tactics and stratergy, an example of what it can be like is 'Avatar of Khaine is very strong but a good opponent could kill him with a handful of troops if he isnt supported', each race can choose between 3 commanders, eldar for example can have a Seer Council Warlock, Farseer or Warp spider commander, Each commander has its own wargear to purchase in game.   All modes are enjoyable, and the game is very well made with a great ammount of detail for an RTS, that being said , last stand and campaign double up as RPG games, I often feel like playing them if I want a change from Torchlight 2 or something similar. 9/10 would highly recommend.   - Con - more could have been done for people who play the game offline, a lot of newer games seem to be very restricting to people who don't want to be online, this is no exception, although The campaign and PvsAI alone is solid enough to merit its very reasonable price tag.

While fun this game doesn't manage to hold my interest like Dawn of War Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. I am also loathe to call it an RTS because it departs from all of the core bits of that game type. There is no base construction at all, or unit construction. What it DOES do well is act more like a real time adaptation of the tabletop game. You command 4 squads on a map to take on various objective. Which squads you take are up to you, within the ones the game makes available, and you can go after 1 optional objective per run. Missions are scored by how you do on several factors, the better you do overall the more XP your squads get. As you level up your squads you can customize their skills and gear. The story is fairly engaging and the voice acting doesn't suck, but also feels like they tried to appeal to a more generic audience than a hardcore Warhammer 40k fan.   Really it feels more like strategy roleplaying game and less real time strategy. 3 out 5 stars imo. Definitely worth it on sale.  edit: and immediately after I post this the game decides it is going to refuse to launch for any reason, files verified as ok just stuck forever at 'preparing to launch' then it did even more weird things. Uninstall time

Fans of the Warhammer universe rejoice! Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War II is the sequel to Dawn of War where the epic tale of the Blood Ravens continues.  Control & Gameplay: Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War ll renews the Dawn of War genre by adding some new core elements. The well known base building and creation of armies have been replaced by tight squad control, where the micromanagement of these squads will lead to a successful mission. You control each squad's loadout, specialization, abilities and generally everything about them. You will also need to take heed of the terrain, where to take cover, where to move and so on. This might seem as a giant leap away from the first Dawn of War series, and it certainly is. It takes some time to become accustomed with the new game mechanics, but once you get settled, the game is quite enjoyable. In campaign mode, each mission will allow you to choose 4 specialized squads who gain XP and items by completing each mission. There is a fixed number of squads to choose from. In multiplayer, the goal is to capture points and hold them, while building additional squads to supplement your commander in battle. The only building available on the field of battle is the headquarters, from which you can spawn more troops.   The controls are accurate and function without any trouble. In multiplayer, however, if a player is experiencing lag issues, it will affect the entire match, thus rendering control of your units more difficult or even impossible, if someone has a high latency. However, this issue is not prevalent, at least not from my experience.   Fun Factor: Apart from the new style of gameplay, which can be a huge turn off for some players, Dawn of War ll is as original in its story as the previous games. The story remains rich and plays a significant part in the game, as you uncover dark secrets regarding the unknown past of the Blood Ravens.  Currently, the game is being converted to Steamworks from Games for Windows Live. Therefore, if anyone chooses to buy the game now, beware that large segments of multiplayer is currently unavailable for use.  Graphics & Audio The visual aspect of the game is a continuation from the previous style: still dark and gritty, but with added details.  The soundtrack is heavy and it enhances the coarse and gritty quality of the game. For the most part, it supplements the game subliminally. After a while, I did not even notice it due to the constant shooting and blowing up of mines, detonation charges and xeno matter flying around.   Replayability: I have spent 100+ hours on this game already, so I would argue that the replayability is indeed high. Even more so with the two expansions: Chaos Rising and Retribution.  In the original Dawn of War 2, there is a campaign and multiplayer mode. Additionally, the campaign can be played both singleplayer and multiplayer through COOP, which I would highly recommend.  Furthermore, another mode was introduced, namely 'The Last Stand'. Here, a group of 3 commandos are pitted against 20 waves of unrelenting xenos. Definitely worth hours of fun and frustration.   Conclusion: Despite the fact that Dawn of War ll has moved away from the original Dawn of War games in terms of mechanics, the game still offers exciting gameplay, a well-structed narrative and solid campaign. Where the older games focused on base building and overwhelming your opponent, the new games focus on managing a handful of specialist squads. Terrain, cover and movement patterns play a larger role in succeeding missions. The game does not run optimally online yet, as the whole net client is being transferred from Games for Windows Live to Steamworks. Therefore, this is the only huge minus about the game, for the time being. This will soon change, and therefore, my rating for this game is positive - 9/10.
The game is alright for those who enjoy commanding a squad but compare to DoW I its a bit of a shame.

Genre - Games Workshop Action RTS  This series is one of the best Warhammer 40K tie-ins I have played and this is the game that started it all. WIth an immersive co-op campaign and skirmish modes. There is also the Last Stand mode, which acts as a multiplayer solo character survival mode.   This is a must have for any Games Workshop 40K fan. Ideally I would suggest getting all the Dawn of War 2 games in a set. However, don't overlook the campaign mode in this game.

Dawn of War II is perhaps the best example of a sequel outside of StarCraft II in the RTS genre. While it tossed out Base Building for a more streamlined approach, it did so with flying colors combining Diablo style loot drops with an RPG leveling system and an extensive skill tree.  Pros: +Decent story with likeable characters +Excellent loot, weapon, armor, and class variety +Great graphics and animations that still hold up to todays standards for RTS games, especially for 2009 +TONS OF CONTENT! On top of a 20+ hour campaign that is highly replayable, you have Co-Op on top of that. (The online modes should be played exclusively on DoW II Retribution though as that has ALL the factions and the majority of the community.) +Fantastic combat with great enemy variety, boss battles, special enemy types, and lots of guns, powers, and toys to play around with +Huge open maps meant for exploration to find loot and other goodies as well as mop up any enemies to rack the experience points. +Decent mission variety with story missions being the most focused with optional Assassination and Defense missions to spice it up +The voice acting is SUPERB with some of the best game actors in the biz working it, including Steve Blum, aka Spike from Cowboy Beebop in this game as a grizzled Sniper expert +ITS WARHAMMER 40K! If you love the franchise like I do you will be splooging at all the detail, lore, and awesome stuff that helps build upon the license and makes you giddy just to feel like youre in the universe of W40K  Con: -Graphics are great overall, but there is some serious texture quality that is left to be desired, like the ground for instance -While the maps are expansive and fun to explore they repeat them CONSTANTLY in the game. It gets repeitive doing the same maps over and over, but it's the quality of the gameplay and the map design that save this unfortunate problem -Cant respec skill tree :( -Still suffers from bugs. Nothing major, but there are occasional animation bugs where units may get stuck or cant move, and enemies who get killed may fly in circles around the map. It's actually kind of funny when you see that one though -Along with repeating maps the missions themselves feel very repetitive after a while. It's the differing enemy types and awesome loot drops that encourage you to play these and save this unforunate repetition -While the writing is passable by W40K fans, most people will see it as stock and cliche. It really is the setting and license that hold it up. The characters are memorable and likeable enough, but fairly one dimensional in personality and you really need to listen to a LOT of their dialog to feel invested  OVERALL: Fantastic I mean no exageration when I award this a 9.5/10 as a W40K fan. As an RTS/RPG fan, I award it an 8.5 for those not familiar with W40K. An excellent game none the less and one of my favorite games of all time and my favorite RTS alongside StarCraft II. An easy buy.

Having been completely obsessed with the first DoW game for years and putting in countless hours into online ranked and frantic base building and huge battles, DoW 2 came as a massive suprise to me. Although I prefer the first game, I can appreciate the change in direction and am enjoying the campaign so far.   I do feel this game is a little tedious at times (I find myself dipping into it for an hour and coming back another time) but maybe this is because, I feel, this is a game that is much more catered to a more casual approach rather than 50 minute, off the scale RTS stratergy battles.   Overall, seeing as I'd give DoW a 10/10, I feel DoW 2 deserves a 6.5. It's quite fun and the customising of your commanders is cool, but I feel like once I've completed the campaign they'll be little in the way to keep me coming back for more.  Here's to DoW3 and the return of base building. Hurrah!

This game is quite different from the previous DoW titles. Before, they were far more like RTSs with resource collection, whereas now, think Company of Heroes but in the 40K universe.  But you also get to level up and gear the squads you want to take with you on your missions - so the perfect mix of RPG and RTS for my taste

Dawn Of War II. The sequel of to DOW which in turn had about 3 expansions.   If you've played the original and are coming into this blind, then be ready for a shock. This doesn't play like a traditional RST game. In fact, it plays more like a Dota style squad based managment game. If you enjoy that kind of game, you'll probably have a right old time with this. The sound design is fantastic. All the guns sounds powerful and weighty, and when someone dies, it doesn't sound good. The graphis also, are a huge step up from the rather dated visuals of the original.   The story this time around isn't as memorable as the first, but a decent romp none the less. The Multiplayer still has a solid community also. However with all that said, I would reccomend skipping this one and buying 'Retribution'. It doesn't require DOWII or it's expansion to play, and includes a lot more content, and a better story.   Final thoughts: Great game, but made redudent by it's superior sequal. If you're fan of squad based, DOTA style gameplay, you might want to pic it up anyway.

Not a member of top-tier RTS games, but a sincere attempt to bring Warhammer 40K to the genre.   The Dawn of War series struggles from one thing more than anything else. It's not Command and Conquer and it's not Starcraft.   If you can accept that, and the extensive expansions you might need to acquire in order to play the preferred race, this game will likely keep you entertained for a number of hours.   I found the campaign to be fine from a story standpoint, but often repetitive and a bit boring when it came to actual game play.   The multiplayer mode was, oddly, lacking some level of immersion. The scale of the battles was quite underwhelming and while the resource acquisition was fine, the objectives were not enough to make up for an experience that was just not very... 40Kish.   I can recommend this game for what it is, a 40K RTS. If you are seeking some RTS experience that immerses you for hours and really give you a new take on the genre, this really isn't the game you are looking for.

Though I love RTS games, I always find myself a little lost commanding an emormous host. I wasn't quite sure what to expect when I picked up DOW II, but I must say I was pleasantly surprised. Commanding smaller groups and sheparding them through missions allows me to focus on best utilizing special abilities and keeping my men alive. My only complaint pertains to the difficulty scale, once you get past the entry level difficulty the boss fights ramp up significantly. This may just be a personal problem though and more experienced RTS players may find the additional challange enjoyable.

I put many highly fun hours into this game a while back. I even edited the wiki, as NEET power nerds are known to do. I never really got into the DLC that much (and holy schmidt, there's a lot of DLC now), but I remember the co-op-able campaign being a very big highlight, as well as the accessibility of the multiplayer 'melee' modes. The lack of dedicated harvesting/building units makes the fights very tactical and actiony. Hero units are a lot of fun to work with, as well. Overall it's a wonderful game with a lot of polish and plenty of content (and also loads and loads of DLC).

Dawn of War II reminds me of something of a hybrid between the addictive, yet brainless Facebook Zynga games (Farmvile, etc) and Company of Heroes. The missions are /mostly/ banal, 'kill or destroy objective X and survive' types that almost feel like MMO quests, yet the character upgrade system and decent story line compel long game sessions. Multiplayer is solid, if not a one-for-one copy of the Company of Heroes, excepting the fun yet underpopulated 'Last Stand' co-op survival mode. Be weary of the 'expansions', except for multiplayer. If you want multiplayer only, skip this and straight for Retribution, which features (almost) ALL units while forging the asinine Games for Windows Live side-program that is built in to DoWII and Chaos Rising.  I should also add that the gameplay style is a MASSIVE departure from the earlyer DoW games, which were traditional RTS games. DoWII is much more of an RPG game than RTS, and has more in common with KOTR and Baldur's Gate than DoW1 or Company of Heroes. If you want an RTS experience, look elsewhere (except multiplayer, which as I said earlier, DoW is just a Warhammer 40k version of Company of Heroes - great but not groundbreaking). If you want a decent, perhaps solid RPG experience with acceptable RTS elements, this is a great choice.

Something I forgot about this game. It doesn't respect your time management. Not being able to save mid-mission is a crippling deficiency for casual gamers. Be prepared to commit 50 minutes to playing a mission, for better or worse, even if you make a crucial error. Because it's never worth rage-quitting, and it's counter-productive to play without being prepared to sink at least 50 minutes into a single mission. Not even any bug-free mods to fix this, either. Can only manually back up save games. Easy mode is therefore the only enjoyable mode for me.

I am running the Linux version and I think there is some things to work on. I think this game got great potential and I played it a lot during its initial release on Windows. However I got to give this a thumbs down because it seems like it never got patched and there are a couple of things that I find broken.  Issues: - Does not run out of the box on some Linux distros because of bad practise when defining LD_PRELOAD_ADDITIONS - The matchmaking in the game mode The Last Stand does not work. It will detect possible games but will not match you with them. This is one of the things I remember as broken since the initial release, the time to find a game in The Last Stand. However in Linux I could leave this on for 20 minutes without finding a game, even though the game presents for me that there are games available and people to match with (this is presented by the UI).  Improvements: - Options to change default keybindings. I think this is a problem with the game in general. You cannot change fundamental keybindings like the map navigation, you are stuck with the arrow keys. - No key to reset the camera angle. This is another fundamental feature that you would expect out of a game like this. If you by mistake change the camera angle you are force to either play with that angle or try to manually find that original angle.

The Dawn of War 40k series of RTS games have always included hundreds of units battling it out in a variety of settings and environments. Now, DOWII offers a more squad-focused style of gameplay, with the single player campaign never allowing more than a dozen or so units to be controlled. While singleplayer is interesting, cinematics are rare and explanation of events can be crude.  The Good Graphics. A huge leap from the 1st generation of DOW games. Smoke, gunfire, enviroment, explosions, look good for an RTS. Cover. More complex (and realistic) means a more strategic use of units is required. Campaign. Although not always straight forward, you have more control over the choices avaliable, i.e, where, when you deploy.  The Bad Scale. DOW games have always been of huuuuge scale. Going to squad sized armies is dissapointing. Storyline. Not always clear why you are fighting in a region.  Repetitive. Combat is almost the same everytime. Pace. Much slower  Score: 6.5/10

If you loved the gameplay for Dawn of War, then you will likely hate this game. Its gameplay is minimilstic and extremely boring.  DoW had actual missions with varying objectives. DoW2's missions are pretty much all the same. Go here, capture this point, then kill the boss. Rinse and repeat until you're dead enough inside that you need to be entombed in a dreadnought. The only break from this monotomy is the occasional defend missions, which are much more enjoyable than the actual campaign missions.  Visually and thematically, the game delivers. Space Marines still look awesome, Orks still look like a bunch of Incredible Hulks that got way into crust punk, and the Eldar still look like teched up Space Elves. Most notably, DoW2 brings the Tyranids to the franchise, which are great looking and have wonderful animations.  However, even the niceties of the game can't save it from the ihghly reptitive missions and the lackluster game mechanics. Even the RPG dressings don't really help.  You only get 4 squad members to deploy on each mission, one of which is always the force commander. So, really, you only get to choose three members of the squad. Choices are: Force Commander, Tactical Squad, Assualt Squad, Heavy Weapons Squad, Dreadnought, and Scout Squad. Once you deploy into the mission, you don't build bases or anything like that. You simply slowly saunter your squads around the map and kill things until you reach the boss. There are points to capture which can replensihg your squad and give you bonuses later on.  After you finish your missions, you get rated on how many enemies you killes, how quickly you completed the map, and how much stuff you captured. XP points allow you to level up squads and give them points to unlock various abilities. You will also find new armor and weapons, with varying stats, for your squads to equip.  I'm sure some love this game simply because it's WH40k. I found this to be an extremely dissapointing sequel. The combat is boring. It's the same crap over and over. Another player in Co-Op means that you control less squads instead of there being more squads. (ie: instead of each player controlling 4 squads, each player controls 2 squads)  If you like building forward bases, tricking the enemy with emplacements, and building up large armies, then you will be completely devistated by this game. None of that is available. Even the Orks feel like their armies are increibly minimalistic and underwhelming when compared to the original DoW. The Multiplayer Annihilation mode is terrible because of the lack of base building capabilities (you always know the enemy base is if you know the map) and the only mode that anyone really plays is Capture Point.  If you like Dawn of War for its gameplay, you will hate DoW2. It's a stripped down version with some useless RPG mechanics that feel like they hinder the gameplay rather than expand it. Which is a shame because the game definitly lives up to what you would expect from a sequel in terms of presentation. But that does mean that if you're simply looking for a WH40k RTS game that looks really good, then this will satisfy that very basic itch.

If you're into RTS games, hate base building, and like unit perk development; this is the game for you. Taking bits from a combat-oriented RPG , minus the dialouge, DoW2 puts a good spin on the RTS. The solo-campaign is engaging, and building a force that plays like you want it to, no matter the unit-type; all this provides hours of enjoyable gameplay. Online Play is a different story, we've been trained to build a base and pump out units. This has you survive, collect resources, survive, hire more units, survive, assault, survive, repeat. You don't have to build structures or buy too many upgrades, but this is closer to traditional RTS multiplay. Finally, the option to Co-Play the solo campaign is unique, intriguing and (unfortunately) something I've yet to try.

The McFist, 'What Year is it?!' Review of Dawn of War 2    Dawn of War 2 [DOW2] is many things, but it is not your original Dawn of War [DOW], nor its expansions. The logistics, so heavily featured in the campaign, and multiplayer [MP], of DOW, and its expansions, have been all but erased from existence in this iteration into the DOW franchise, and have been replaced with an extreme emphasis on tactical placement of but a few squads, both in the campaign and in MP. In fact, one of the only comparrisons I can make between the campaign and MP portions of the game, thsu I will discuss the campaign portion of DOW2, then dive headlong into the MP aspect.  In DOW2, you are the a newly appointed Force Commander for the Blood Ravens, the faction of the Space Marines that were the primary protagonist in DOW. Assigned to Calderis to aid Captain Thule, you take command of the Force Commander and a squad of Tactical Marines, lead by Sargeant Tarkus, to crush an Ork uprising. During the Calderis missions you are introduced to other squads (Assault Marines, Scouts, and Devastator Marines) that you can bring with you, and use, during the campaign. Each squad has a designated 'hero' in its ranks, and for the Tactical Marines it is Sargeant Tarkus. The squad can lose members in battle, and have its number replenished at waypoint beacons. However, if the 'hero' takes too much damage, he will be incapacitated (all units in the squad will die), and will need to be revived by another squad. You can tell if the 'hero' is taking damage by looking to their icon at the side of the screen, which will display the 'hero's' health as well as how many marines are alive (blank person icons incidate that the squad is down men).  During the campaign, you can only deploy four squads at one time. You must make your selection, and choose carefully as you cannot switch out squads in-mission. The Force Commander must always be deployed with your team, however you can switch out the others, depending on the tactics you wish to employ during your mission, with ease. And, with the removal of logistics in this game, tactics are very important in order to keep your squads alive.  In DOW2, you will encounter something very familiar to you, if you have played Company of Heroes [COH]: color-graded cover. Muck akin to COH, when you position your squads, your cursor will show you how good the cover is, by displaying yellow, or green, colored circles. During the campaign, it is quintessential to place your units in cover, as on higher difficulties, your squads can be eliminated in seconds if they are in open terrain. This also applies to enemy units that find themselves without cover.   Each killed unit will garner your squads experience [EXP] during the mission, while undeployed squads will only receive a partial EXP boost. Your squads will gain levels and be granted two points, each level-up, to spend on 4 different trees: Stamina, Range, Melee, and Energy. For every 5 points in a tree, the squad will be gain a new ability, ranging from using a melee power, of having the passive power enabling the use of Terminator Armor. Depending on where the points are placed, this will dictate how you are wanting to use this squad in combat. You can make each squad different each time you play, depending on where you allocate their points.  However, it must be said that if you are inexperienced with micromanaging units, you could struggle, and be overwhelmed, with all the powers, abilities, and items that each squad can use, not to mention trying to tactically place 4 squads before an engagement begins, or has already begun.  And, during missions, you will also receive loot, such as weapons and armor, that can be equipped to your squads. Some items can only be used by certain squads, however, and some items will require you to wait until you are a high enough level to use them.  After you complete each mission, you are graded by three things: Fury [amount of enemies killed] Speed [completion time] Resilience [how many squads were incapactitated]. You are then awarded between 1-5 stars for each category, which is then talied into your rank. This rank is meaningless essentially, save for achievements on Games for Windows Live, a service that will thankfully be no more next year.  The story in DOW2. though, is your standard affair with the DOW series. The Blood Ravens must rise to the challange and overcome their enemies. The story requires little thought, as you are ordered to go several different planets to stop enemy uprisings and to ultimately stop the biggest threat to the sector:    The Tyranids   .  The real challenge in this game's campaign is to keep your squads alive, and that's what keeps me coming back to this series. I embrace the challenge of finding my sqauds overwhelmed, yet are able to hold off the hordes of xenos and not lose a single squad in the fight. If the challenge of keeping soldiers alive in XCOM: Enemy Unknown was what kept you going, then this game is definitely for you.  One final thought about the campaign, though: You can Co-op the story. And Co-op is where the story's gameplay shines.  No longer tasked with commanding four squads, you and your partner will comand two squads each, though the host must always keep the Force Commander with them, if I recall correctly. Only needing to command two units each, the squad management is much easier to grasp and learn, which can also act as a learning tool if you wish to play the story by yourself again. Both players can assign points to, and equip, each squad, even ones they are not actually in control of. But, keep in mind that Player 2 does not save any progress for the Co-op campaign, as it is saved only for the host. Player 2 will have to start the campaign fresh, if they have not played the game at all before playing Co-op.  While that is a small misstep for the Co-op portion of the campaign, the rest is truly fantastic and nothing beats the feeling of you and your partner working together, taking out squad after squad of enemies without taking a scratch.    Last Stand    DOW2 also features a new, MP, Co-op horde-mode style gametype known as Last Stand. Last Stand is a three-player game mode in which you each pick one hero to do battle with against waves of enemies. You hero will receive EXP and level up during your playthrough. However, instead of gaining points to level your hero up with, you are given items for each level up that can be used to make a supremely deadly build. Each hero has to be leveled individually. Expect to fail in this game mode often.    Multiplayer    In DOW2's MP, you can expect to see a game very reminiscent to COH. You are required to capture Requisition and Power points in order to train units, and to level up your Tech Level, at your HQ, as to create higher-teir units. You have no buildings you need to create in order to build units. Cover is essential, just like in the campaign, as is the unit's positioning. Devastator Marines can be easily overcome if they are flanked. The rest is your standard affair with COH. Expect few units early, and many often.  With that said, the MP portion of this game is quite boring, in my experience, and I have found little entertainment in it. But, other, who have spent far more time in this game, may disagree with me.   But if you want a single-player and Co-op experience in the DOW universe, that abandons logistics for a tactical, real-time, action RPG than look no further than this, as it sates those needs perfectly.

Strategy games have long been about who can build the most massive number of units the fastest in order to simply overwhelm the other player. Dawn of War II's cover system and 5 distinct races make for a play experience that is challenging in every engagement, not just a coin toss win/lose situation. Dawn of War 2… ahh… Dawn of War 2… having been a 40k fan for decades, and a DoW 1 junkie, I bought this game the day it came out. I had high hopes for an even more advanced DoW experience.  I played it for about 7 hours… and put it down until the past week. Yep. I ignored this game for over 6 years. Upon playing it in 2009, I was very disappointed, but we’ll get to that below.  So why did I pick it back up? I just loaded up on Sega games due to the sale last week (Sega bought THQ), and decided to go ahead and trudge through this game. I had heard good things about Chaos Rising/Retribution and wanted to get through the base DoW2 experience before moving on so I’d have an idea of what the heck was going on in the expansions.  I’m on the last mission of the campaign. And wow… it’s been somewhat painful to get through (and not because it’s hard… there’s very little that is hard in this game). Here’s the skinny:  Pros: - Awesome Graphics. - Tyranids as an enemy/playable outside of the campaign - Great terrain engine (destructible, affects line of sight very well… similar/same tech as found in Call of Heroes) - Detailed and somewhat interesting character RPG-style progression with loot and XP (caveat in cons below). It’s very reminiscent of the old WH:40k – Chaos Gate game (with way less detail and minus perma death)  The real highlight of the game is leveling up your characters. It’s fun watching them go from being more or less a base line Space Marine with basic gear of their specific type from the TT game (HQ, Tac, Heavy, Assault), to a fleshed out bad ♥♥♥ toting WMDs.  Cons: - No base building, and no tech tree. This game is not REALLY an RTS in that sense. It’s more like a multi-unit Diablo-like Hack n' Slasher (with guns). - The game difficulty is low. The only really hard part of the game is baby-sitting your units because they don’t respond the way you initially tell them to sometimes (see pathing issues below). In fact, if you are losing a fight, you can click a “Flee” button and escape to a reinforcement point at double speed. Most the time the enemy won’t pursue. To fail a mission ALL your units have to get killed. As long as one is standing, you have a chance to go resurrect them and flee. I’ve only lost one mission out of 30-40 because I got distracted IRL. - Every mission is centered on the same 4-6 Space Marines. Literally… you play the same 6 characters and their token squad members… every… map… and usually only 4 at a time. And when I say token squad members, that’s nearly meant literally. They are not represented outside of the mission other than to be a backdrop on the character screen. They are always the first to die, and they are instantly replaced if you flee to a reinforcement point. - The RPG system is unforgiving (the caveat mentioned above). Not spending your ability points correctly from the get go WILL bite you in the rear later as you’ll be short points to unlock the next trait. And you can’t reset them. Also, you can’t max out on ability points. You get 40. Period. (2 per level, levels hard cap at 20). Either pick your ability layout before starting your campaign or you will be screwed. - There are pathing problems with certain maps and character pathing AI. I’ve had units get stuck in the side of a hill and wouldn’t move. Additionally, you’ll constantly have Assault Marines or the Force Commander set to “Melee” response, and during a scrum they’ll be standing there shooting because they can’t figure out how to get to the enemy, even though the path has been cleared up. Or, you’ll tell all your units to move up into firing range. The Heavy unit will engage, but the shorter range Tactical will stop with the Heavies and not engage the target. It’s maddeningly frustrating to baby sit your units. - The map design, while graphically gorgeous, is very poor. Almost every map is just lanes of choke point after choke point between objectives. - The campaign makes little sense from a “tactical” standpoint. You are forced to jump back and forth between three star systems on a mostly linear campaign, but you wind up fighting all three factions all over the place. There are side missions to do, but other than gearing up with new loot, they affect the campaign in very minimal ways. And lastly, the maps are all repeated ad nauseam even for the main campaign missions. - The scope of the story, while very much the a-typical Tyranid sector invasion, which is fine… is yet still borderline absurd. Looking at what we know about Space Marines,. You’re flying around in a Blood Ravens Strike Cruiser (which holds a whole company of Space Marines and war gear). And the only resources you can use are a Force Commander, a Tactical Squad that is short a member, a Devastator Squad and Assault Squad that are both short two members, a full scout squad, and later a Dreadnaught? Why don’t we have Land Speeders at the least? The orks have tanks and trukks. And you mean to tell me that 4 incomplete squads are going to affect a Tyranid invasion to the point of forcing them off-world? Uh. No. I’m pretty sure there were many more Space Marines at the Battle of Macragge when Hive Fleet Behemoth was repelled. - Boss battles are out of line with 40k cannon. Many exhibit toughness and some abilities that have no frame of reference in the 40k mythos. For example… a Warp Spider Exarch would be WAY outmatched while fighting off 4 squads of Space Marines WITH a Force Commander. That fight wouldn’t take nearly as long. There are other bosses too that don’t make sense.  So as you can see, in the overall scheme of things, DoW2 was a big letdown. I guess if you’re new to strategy games or haven’t played other 40k games, it could seem really fun. And the RPG thing is kind of neat. But even that is flawed, and it doesn’t make up for all the other problems with the game.  I can’t say I recommend this game. I’m just glad I got the expansions for like $4 each.

Among my favorite Warhammer titles and favorite strategy games period, Dawn of War II is the beginning of a three-part epic tale of the battle for the Blood Ravens' recruitment worlds, continued with the Chaos Rising expansion and concluded in the stand-alone Retribution. This title reperesented a considerable departure gameplay wise from the first Dawn of War and its expansions, moving away from base building, resource gathering and large-scale battles towards a smaller squad tactics format seen in the earlier Company of Heroes series, from which Dawn of War II borrowed its graphics engine: a shift that was not universally welcomed. Dawn of War II is a blend of real-time squad tactics and an RPG loot-and-level system that I found deeply engrossing. The campaign is heavily story-driven and takes you to a variety of environments, including the interior of a space hulk made famous by the turn-based series of that name. Excellent music, visual effects and voice work accompany the proceedings. Series mainstays the Space Marines, Orks and Eldar returned, along with newcomers in the fearsome Tyranids, not featured in the first game due to, supposedly, engine limitations. Epic, pitched battles and a surprising end-game return of a popular character from the first game wrapped up the experience for me in the best way possible. The main flaw of DOW II was its use of the Games For Windows Live client, but it has since been updated to remove that particular pustule. An excellent title overall and worth playing today.
